awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Collaborative Research: Collective Mining of Vertical Social Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
A large fraction of internet social media content is found in thousands of specialized communities that are hosted by news outlets, typically in the form of reader forums or comments on news articles. The users of the such a site are said to form a vertical social community (VSC), because they deeply engage with a single media source.  While each VSC is tiny compared to broad communities such as Facebook, they are important because they expose how different segments of society feel about various world events. This can be a very useful resource for downstream intelligence and predictive analytics.  However, current web crawlers cannot effectively access VSCs. Thus their data is invisible to search engines, and remains hidden from analytics tools.  The goals of this project are to enable effective access to vertical social communities coalesced at news reports online, and to mine their comments and debates. This project will provide researchers with tools to collect data from these communities and analyze them.  The educational component of the project includes the involvement of graduate and undergraduate student training and research and the incorporation of research projects and results in courses.

The researchers will develop algorithms to unearth the content generated at thousands of vertical social communities and make their content transparently accessible to data management and analytics tools. The researchers will develop novel deep learning techniques for content detection, and build a novel scalable end-to-end system for real-time access and collective mining of these communities, capable of handling large parallel data streams based on shifting ideas. The specific algorithms will include user population estimation, bootstrap communication patterns for automatic crawling of content, and fine-grained sentiment analysis for intelligence and predictive analytics. Software tools will be made available to researchers in academe and industry. Distribution of free, open-source software for implementing the techniques developed will enhance existing research infrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to develop novel models for content analysis for social media. Deception detection was given significant focus as it is a prerequisite for effective sentiment and content analysis on user generated content.

Under deception detection several models were explored for claim verification, evidence retrieval for claim verification, authorship attribution (i.e., ascertaining whether two documents are written by the same author). Further, holistic models were proposed to treat deception as a domain independent phenomenon, i.e., robust models that are capable of detecting deceptive content across a variety of domains (e.g., email spam, phishing, fake news, rumor tweets) beyond traditional fake news and combine multiple domains to explore more robust deceptive content classifiers.

Under opinion modeling, focused neural models were developed for personality modeling and user opinion fingerprinting for future opinion and response prediction.

We believe the above results and models provide a foundation and intellectual capital for combating deceptive content online, improve the trustworthiness of user generated content online, and help detect online harassment, bigotry, trolls that are of major relevance to security.

Additionally, the models developed for opinion and personality modeling provide a solid base for a variety of content mining and situational awareness disciplines and provide a near real time assessment of social response and public opinion on trending events.

The above results appear in the following papers that were published during the project.

 

1. Marjan Hosseinia, Eduard Dragut and Arjun Mukherjee. Stance Prediction for Contemporary Issues: Data and Experiments. The 8th International Workshop on Natural Language Processing for Social Media (SocialNLP?20). July 9-10, 2020, Seattle, Washington, USA. https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.00052

2. Yigeng Zhang, Fan Yang, Yifan Zhang, Eduard Dragut and Arjun Mukherjee. Birds of a Feather Flock Together: Satirical News Detection via Language Model Differentiation. International Conference on Social Computing, Behavioral-Cultural Modeling & Prediction and Behavior Representation in Modeling and Simulation (SBP?20). Oct 19 - 21, 2020 in Washington DC, USA.

3. Lihong He, Chao Han, Arjun Mukherjee, Zoran Obradovic, Eduard C. Dragut. On the dynamics of user engagement in news comment media. Wiley Interdiscip. Rev. Data Min. Knowl. Discov. 10(1) (2020).

4. Lihong He, Chen Shen, Arjun Mukherjee, Slobodan Vucetic, Eduard Dragut. Cannot Predict Comment Volume of a News Article before (a few) Users Read It. (ICWSM 2021). Jan. 2021.

5. Marjan Hosseinia, Eduard Dragut, and Arjun Mukherjee. Pro/Con: Neural Detection of Stance in Argumentative Opinions. International Conference on Social Computing, Behavioral-Cultural Modeling & Prediction and Behavior Representation in Modeling and Simulation (SBP?19). July 9 - 12, 2019 in Washington DC, USA

6. Yifan Zhang, Dainis Boumber, Marjan Hosseinia, Fan Yang and Arjun Mukherjee. Improving Authorship Verification using Linguistic Divergence. ROMCIR '21, Mar 28, Apr 1 2021, Lucca Italy.

7. Amartya Hatua, Arjun Mukherjee and Rakesh Verma. On the Feasibility of Using GANs for Claim VerificationExperiments and Analysis. ROMCIR '21, Mar 28, Apr 1 2021, Lucca Italy.

8. Fan Yang, Eduart Dragut, and Arjun Mukherjee. Claim Verification under Positive Unlabeled Learning. ASONAM?20, 7-10 Dec 2020.

9. Fan Yang, Eduart Dragut, and Arjun Mukherjee. Predicting Personal Opinion on Future Events with Fingerprints. COLING?20, 8-13 Dec 2020, Barcelona, Spain.

10. Sadat Shahriar, Omprakash Gnawali, and Arjun Mukherjee. A Domain-Independent Holistic Approach to Deception Detection. In proceedings of the Conference on Recent Advances in Natural Language Processing, 2021.

11. Fan Yang, Eduart Dragut, and Arjun Mukherjee. Improving Evidence Retrieval with Claim-Evidence Entailment. In proceedings of the Conference on Recent Advances in Natural Language Processing, 2021.

12. Amartya Hatua, Arjun Mukherjee, Rakesh Verma. Claim Verification using a Multi-GAN based Model. In proceedings of the Conference on Recent Advances in Natural Language Processing, 2021.

13. Marjan Hosseinia, Eduard Dragut, Dainis Boumber, and Arjun Mukherjee. On the Usefulness of Personality Traits in Opinion-oriented Tasks. In proceedings of the Conference on Recent Advances in Natural Language Processing. 1-3 September 2021.

14. Kishore Tumarada, Yifan Zhang, Fan Yang, Eduard Dragut, Omprakash Gnawali, and Arjun Mukherjee. Opinion Prediction with User Fingerprinting. In proceedings of the Conference on Recent Advances in Natural Language Processing. 1-3 September 2021.

The research resulted in a total of 14 papers that were published in leading venues over a period of 4 years. The papers have acknowledged NSF support. Over the entire course of the project, it supported 4 PhD (of which 1 was female) students, 2 interns and 1MS student in their professional development apart from progress in science.
